title: American_Top_40_1976_October_23rd
description:
"From the rocky coast of Maine to the sandy shores of Hawaii, you hear the nation's biggest hits every week at this time on AT40. I'm Casey Kasem and the countdown continues now with Fleetwood Mac and the third big hit from that big album called Fleetwood Mac, 'Say You Love Me'."


American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This is a recording of a rebroadcast from internet radio.

In this broadcast:

A listener wants to know which of Motown's many number one hits held the number one spot the longest. Casey says it was the longest song title that ever hit number one for Motown.

"A Little Bit More" (at number 28) by Dr. Hook & the Medicine Show was originally written and recorded by Bobby Gosh, who quit the music business after failing to find success. Casey plays a piece of the original.

Casey remembers Roger Williams, the man who had more piano hits on the singles and album charts than anybody else in history and was also the most successful boxer at his military installation where he put in his service.

When introducing the song "Beth" (at number 17) Casey reports Gene Simmons as saying KISS would never perform without their make-up. Never say never!

Casey reflects on the influence of Buddy Holly.

A listener wants to know, "What artist has hit the charts under the most different names, whether on his own or as a member of groups?" This artist has been identified on record labels in eight different ways.
